questions.text: A clinician is testing the function of myotomes in the upper and lower extremities via isometric resisted muscle testing. This provides the clinician with information regarding the level in the spine where a lesion may be present. Which of the following best describes the embryological origin of a myotome?
questions.solution:
The paraxial mesoderm is a tube-shaped structure surrounding the notochord. It becomes divided into segmented round cell clusters (somites) along the neural tube (week 4). Up to the beginning of week 5, an initial 42–44 somite pairs are formed in a craniocaudal direction. Degeneration of several somite pairs, so that 35–37 somite pairs remain. The ventral region of each somite forms a sclerotome (bone-forming cells) and the upper region of each somite forms a dermatome plus two muscle-forming areas (myotomes). The myotome forms a subdivision into the dorsal epimere and ventral hypomere skeletal muscles in the lateral and anterior regions of the thorax and abdomen.  

Option Analysis

❌ Axial mesoderm:
Incorrect: The axial mesoderm is located in the central region of the mesoderm and gives rise to the notochord and prechordal mesoderm. It does not form the myotome.  
✅ Paraxial mesoderm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lateral plate mesoderm  :
Incorrect: The lateral plate mesoderm lies lateral to the intermediate mesoderm. It folds  and splits horizontally to form the somatic mesoderm (differentiates into the lining of the pleural, pericardial, and peritoneal cavities) and the splanchnic mesoderm (differentiates into the visceral lining of internal organs). It does not form the myotome.  
❌ Intermediate mesoderm:
Incorrect: The intermediate mesoderm lies lateral to the paraxial mesoderm and gives rise to the urogenital fold, consisting of the nephrogenic ridge and the genital ridge. It does not form the myotome.  
❌ Surface ectoderm  :
Incorrect: The surface ectoderm forms the epidermis; adenohypophysis (from Rathke pouch); the lens of eye; epithelial linings of the oral cavity, sensory organs of the ear, and olfactory epithelium; anal canal below the pectinate line; parotid, sweat, and mammary glands.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the structure and function of human fetal circulation. Which of the following best describes the pattern of blood flow in the fetus from the placenta to systemic circulation?

choices.text: Placenta→Aorta→common iliac arteries→internal and external iliac arteries→umbilical arteries

questions.solution:
Fetal circulation is different from the adult circulatory system. It allows a developing fetus to receive oxygenated blood and nutrients from the placenta. Fetal gas exchange begins in the placenta, where one umbilical vein supplies oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus and two umbilical arteries deliver deoxygenated blood back to the placenta.  

The circulatory pathway from the placenta to the fetal systemic circulation is as follows. The placenta drains oxygenated blood into the umbilical vein, which then divides into the larger ductus venosus and smaller portal sinus. Most of the blood flows through the ductus venosus directly into the inferior vena cava. A smaller amount of blood enters the liver via the portal sinus and mixes with the blood from the portal circulation which then drains into the inferior vena cava. From the inferior vena cava, blood flows directly into the right atrium.  

Once blood is in the right atrium, most of it flows into the lower-pressure left atrium via the foramen ovale, and then into the left ventricle. From there, it is delivered into the systemic circulation via the aorta. A smaller amount of blood from the right atrium enters the right ventricle into the pulmonary artery, which is largely delivered to the descending aorta via the ductus arteriosus. From here, oxygenated blood is supplied to the rest of the body, and deoxygenated blood is returned to the descending aorta to flow toward the placenta by way of two umbilical arteries.

Option Analysis

✅ Placenta→Umbilical Vein→ductus venosus→Inferior vena cava  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Placenta→Portal sinus→liver→Inferior vena cava  :
Incorrect: Blood must first pass through the umbilical vein in fetal circulation.  
❌ Placenta→Umbilical Vein→ductus arteriosus→Inferior vena cava  :
Incorrect: From the umbilical vein, most of the oxygenated blood flows into the ductus venosus (not arteriosus) into the systemic circulation. Ductus arteriosus connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta.  
❌ Placenta→Aorta→common iliac arteries→internal and external iliac arteries→umbilical arteries  :
Incorrect: Placenta delivers oxygenated blood into the umbilical vein, not the aorta.  
❌ Placenta→Umbilical artery→Aorta  :
Incorrect: Placenta delivers oxygenated blood into the umbilical vein, not the umbilical artery.

questions.text: Gastrulation is a vital process for early human development. Which of the following is true regarding gastrulation?

choices.text: It occurs during week four of fetal development
It involves the formation of the bilaminar disc
It gives the embryo its specific head-to-tail and front-to-back orientation
The neural plate is transformed into the neural tube
The trophoblast forms the cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast during this stage

questions.solution:
During week 3 of human development, the blastocyst undergoes gastrulation, which begins around day 14. Gastrulation starts with forming the primitive groove, a narrow depression that runs down the center of the epiblast layer. This groove defines the cranial-caudal axis, and the two sides of the groove represent the first instance of bilateral symmetry in the embryo. The round bilaminar disc also elongates (narrow at the caudal end and broad at the cranial end). At the cranial end of the primitive groove, a small mound of tissue develops called the primitive node, and a tiny dimple forms within it called the primitive pit. The primitive groove, primitive node, and primitive pit together form the primitive streak. 

The epiblast cells migrate towards the primitive groove to the bottom and slide under (invagination). After invagination, cells differentiate into three new layers of the embryonic disc (trilaminar disc):

 -          Some epiblast cells displace the ventral hypoblast layer and form endoderm 

-          Others come to lie between the epiblast and newly created endoderm to form mesoderm.  

-          Rest of the epiblast forms an ectoderm layer  

Cells of trilaminar disc multipotent (ability to differentiate into many tissues and organs).  


Option Analysis

❌ It occurs during week four of fetal development  :
Incorrect: Gastrulation occurs during week three of fetal development.  
❌ It involves the formation of the bilaminar disc  :
Incorrect: The bilaminar disc forms during week two of fetal development. Gastrulation consists of the formation of three germ layers from epiblast cells.  
✅ It gives the embryo its specific head-to-tail and front-to-back orientation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ The neural plate is transformed into the neural tube  :
Incorrect: The transformation of the neural plate into the neural tube is called neurulation, which occurs during week 4 of fetal development.  
❌ The trophoblast forms the cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast during this stage  :
Incorrect: The trophoblast forms cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast during week 2 of human development.

questions.text: A group of investigators is classifying the pharyngeal apparatus derivatives for an upcoming project. Which of the following is true regarding the pharyngeal pouch derivatives?

choices.text: The fourth pharyngeal pouch forms mastoid air cells
Pierre Robin sequence results from the abnormal development of the first and second pharyngeal pouches
Structures from the third pouch end up below those from the fourth pouch
Pharyngeal pouches are derived from the mesoderm and neural crest cells
The greater horn of the hyoid is derived from the third pharyngeal pouch

questions.solution:
The pharyngeal pouches form on the endodermal side between the pharyngeal arches. The first pouch contributes to the ear's endoderm-lined structures, including the middle ear cavity, eustachian tube, and mastoid air cells; the second pharyngeal pouch forms the epithelial lining of the palatine tonsil. The third pouch and fourth pouch are very similar in that they divide into a dorsal and ventral portion. Structures from the third pouch end up below those from the fourth pouch. The dorsal portion of the third pouch becomes the inferior parathyroid glands, while the dorsal portion of the fourth pouch becomes the superior parathyroid glands. The ventral portion of the third pouch becomes the primitive thymus, which later descends into the chest. The ventral portion of the fourth pouch becomes the ultimo pharyngeal body which differentiates into parafollicular (C) cells of the thyroid.
 

Option Analysis

❌ The fourth pharyngeal pouch forms mastoid air cells:
Incorrect: The first pharyngeal pouch forms the mastoid air cells.  
❌ Pierre Robin sequence results from the abnormal development of the first and second pharyngeal pouches :
Incorrect: Pierre Robin sequence results from the abnormal development of the first and second pharyngeal arches, not pouches.  
✅ Structures from the third pouch end up below those from the fourth pouch:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pharyngeal pouches are derived from the mesoderm and neural crest cells  :
Incorrect: Pharyngeal pouches are derived from the endoderm.  
❌ The greater horn of the hyoid is derived from the third pharyngeal pouch  :
Incorrect: The greater horn of the hyoid is derived from the third pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: An investigator is studying congenital penile anomalies in a human embryo. Faulty positioning of the genital tubercle in a male embryo can lead to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Differentiation and development of the external genitalia occurs during weeks 8-15 of gestation. In females, the genital tubercle forms the clitoris. In males, it forms the glans penis.

Epispadias is a rare abnormality (1/30,000 births) in which the urethral meatus is found on the dorsal (top) surface of the penis. Instead of developing at the cranial margin of the cloacal membrane, the genital tubercle forms in the region of the urorectal septum--hence a portion of the cloacal membrane is found cranial to the genital tubercle. When this membrane ruptures, the outlet of the urogenital sinus comes to lie on the cranial aspect of the penis. Although epispadias may occur as an isolated defect, it is most often associated with exstrophy of the bladder.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bifid scrotum  :
Incorrect: A bifid scrotum results from malunion of the labioscrotal (genital) swellings. In females, these swellings form the labia majora.  
✅ Epispadias:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Hypospadias:
Incorrect: Hypospadias refers to the abnormal opening of the penile urethra on the ventral (under) surface due to failure of urethral folds to fuse.  
❌ Cryptorchidism:
Incorrect: Cryptorchidism results from failure of a fetal testis to descend into the scrotum. Most undescended testes descend spontaneously by 4 months of age. The remainder require surgical intervention to decrease the risk of infertility and malignant transformation.  
❌ Hydrocele of the testis:
Incorrect: Hydrocele of the testis is development of a fluid-filled peritoneal sac within the scrotum that results from incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis. The processus vaginalis is a projection of the peritoneal cavity that accompanies the descending testis into the scrotum.

questions.text: A total thyroidectomy is performed for a patient with papillary thyroid cancer. During an attempt to ligate the inferior thyroid artery, a nerve nearby is inadvertently damaged. Following the operation, the patient develops hoarseness and difficulty speaking. Which of the following embryological structures gave rise to the damaged structure in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient likely suffers from hoarseness due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury during surgery. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is derived from the sixth pharyngeal arch. The inferior thyroid artery lies near the recurrent laryngeal nerve as it approaches the thyroid, susceptible to damage.

The pharyngeal apparatus consists of branchial clefts, arches, and pouches, which give rise to many of the structures in the face and neck. The sixth pharyngeal arch gives rise to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (branch of CN X) and all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid. The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the larynx to allow for voice production.

On the other hand, the fourth pharyngeal arch gives rise to the pharyngeal constrictors, cricothyroid muscle, muscles of the soft palate, and superior laryngeal nerve (branch of CN X).  

Option Analysis

❌ First pharyngeal arch:
Incorrect: The first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the mandible, malleus, incus, muscles of mastication, mylohyoid, tensor tympani, tensor veli palatini, and CN V2/V3.  
❌ Second pharyngeal arch  :
Incorrect: The second pharyngeal arch gives rise to the stapes, styloid process, lesser horn of the hyoid, stylohyoid ligament, muscles of facial expression, stapedius, stylohyoid muscle, and CN VII.  
❌ Third pharyngeal arch:
Incorrect: The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to the greater horn of the hyoid, stylopharyngeus muscle, and CN IX.  
❌ Fourth pharyngeal arch  :
Incorrect: The fourth pharyngeal arch gives rise to the pharyngeal constrictors, cricothyroid muscle, muscles of the soft palate, and the superior laryngeal nerve (branch of CN X).  
✅ Sixth pharyngeal arch  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying fetal erythropoiesis at different stages of fetal development.  Which of the following best reflects the predominant hemoglobin chain composition at the 18<sup>th</sup> week of gestation?

choices.text: Two alpha and two gamma chains (ɑ2γ2)
Two zeta and two epsilon chains (�2ϵ2)
Two alpha and two beta chains (ɑ2β2)

questions.solution:
Several types of hemoglobin exist throughout fetal development, with fetal hemoglobin (HbF) being the predominant form during gestation. HbF is composed of two alpha and two gamma chains (ɑ2γ2).  

HbF differs from adult hemoglobin (HbA) in that it contains two gamma chains, which have a decreased affinity to 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG). 2,3-BPG is a metabolic intermediate produced in tissues with high energy use. Due to its less avid binding with 2,3-BPG, HbF has a higher affinity for oxygen, which allows it to extract oxygen from maternal hemoglobin (HbA1 and HbA2) across the placenta.  

Additional forms of hemoglobin include embryonic hemoglobin (composed of two zeta and two epsilon chains [�2ϵ2] chains), as well as pathologic hemoglobin compositions like Hb Barts (γ4) and Hb H (β4). The former is seen in alpha-thalassemia major, while the latter is seen in alpha thalassemia intermedia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Two alpha and two gamma chains (ɑ2γ2)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Two zeta and two epsilon chains (�2ϵ2)  :
Incorrect: Mainly formed in the yolk sac and liver, zeta and epsilon hemoglobin chains comprise embryonic hemoglobin, which is present in fetal circulation until approximately 8-10 weeks of gestation.  
❌ Two alpha and two beta chains (ɑ2β2)  :
Incorrect: Two alpha and two beta chains comprise adult hemoglobin, not fetal hemoglobin. Adult hemoglobin is mainly formed in the bone marrow.  
❌ Four gamma chains (γ4)  :
Incorrect: Four gamma chains form Hemoglobin Barts (Hb-Barts), which have an incredibly high affinity for oxygen. It is produced in the alpha-thalassemia major and in the most severe of cases, it is the only form of hemoglobin in circulation.   
❌ Four beta chains (β4)  :
Incorrect: Four beta chains form the Hemoglobin H (Hb H) which is seen in Hb H disease. It is seen in alpha thalassemia intermedia.

questions.text: The fetal extraembryonic membranes form in the uterus during the first weeks of development and include the amniotic sac, yolk sac, chorion, and allantois. Which of the following best describes the chorion?

choices.text: It develops from the hypoblast on day 9 of fetal development .
It develops chorionic villi and invades endometrium to form the fetal part of the placenta.
It is a thick layer of decidua basalis that maternal spiral arteries and veins pass through.
It serves as a canal through which urine is eliminated before the urethra develops.
It is a space that appears between epiblast and cytotrophoblast on day 8 of fetal development .

questions.solution:
During day 8 of fetal development, a tiny space called the amniotic cavity forms between the epiblast and cytotrophoblast. The epiblast cells migrate to form a thin membrane called the amnion that surrounds the amniotic cavity, separating it from the cytotrophoblast.  

The chorion is a fibrous tissue composed of a layer of extraembryonic mesoderm, cytotrophoblasts, and syncytiotrophoblasts. On day 10 of fetal development, it is formed when the epiblast cells differentiate into the extraembryonic mesoderm between the amniotic cavity/yolk sac and cytotrophoblast. Eventually, a space called extraembryonic coelom/chorionic cavity forms within this layer. The cavity continues to expand until there is only a thin layer of extraembryonic mesoderm lining the amniotic cavity/yolk sac and cytotrophoblast. Eventually, the amnion and the chorion fuse and form the amniotic sac.  

Option Analysis

❌ It develops from the hypoblast on day 9 of fetal development .:
Incorrect: On day 9 of fetal development, the hypoblast cells migrate to form a thin membrane around the blastocoel, forming the walls of the yolk sac. The yolk sac fills with vitelline fluid, nourishing the embryo.  
✅ It develops chorionic villi and invades endometrium to form the fetal part of the placenta.:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ It is a thick layer of decidua basalis that maternal spiral arteries and veins pass through.  :
Incorrect: The basal plate is a thick layer of decidua basalis tissue through which maternal spiral arteries and veins pass.  
❌ It serves as a canal through which urine is eliminated before the urethra develops.:
Incorrect: The allantois is a canal through which urine is eliminated before the urethra develops.
❌ It is a space that appears between epiblast and cytotrophoblast on day 8 of fetal development .:
Incorrect: The amniotic sac is the space that appears between epiblast and cytotrophoblast on day 8 of fetal development.

questions.text: An autopsy of a stillborn boy reveals fused cerebral hemispheres with absent forebrain fissures and a single intracranial ventricle. Mutations in which of the following gene is the most likely cause of these autopsy findings?
questions.solution:
This stillborn fetus most likely has holoprosencephaly, where the brain does not correctly divide into two distinct hemispheres.  The mutated gene is most likely the sonic hedgehog gene (SHH).   

The sonic hedgehog (SHH) protein is highly expressed at the zones of polarizing activity at the base of limb buds. It regulates the differentiation of somites along the anteroposterior axis and the neural tube. Mutations can cause holoprosencephaly (due to failed forebrain cleavage).   

Option Analysis

✅ Sonic the Hedgehog gene  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Wnt-7 gene  :
Incorrect: Wnt-7 is a gene that is necessary for proper organ organization along the dorsal-ventral axis. While a mutation in this gene can affect the midbrain, this defect does not result in holoprosencephaly.  
❌ Fibroblast growth factor gene  :
Incorrect: Fibroblast growth factor (FGF) gene stimulates mitosis of underlying mesoderm, which causes limb lengthening. Mutations would result in short and poorly developed limbs.  
❌ Homeobox gene  :
Incorrect: Homeobox (Hox) genes are involved in the segmental organization of the embryo in a cranial to caudal direction. Hox mutations result in the development of appendages in the wrong location.  
❌ PAX:
Incorrect: PAX is responsible for developing some specific tissues and is involved in the pathogenesis of aniridia.

questions.text: A group of researchers studying the reproduction process discover that beta-hcG levels are first detected in serum following implantation of the blastocyst. When does blastocyst implant into the uterus?
questions.solution:
During fertilization, the zygote undergoes the process of cleavage, where it divides into a new pair of cells called blastomeres. The blastomeres divide several times to form a mulberry-shaped 16-cell cluster called a morula, with inner and outer cell masses. The morula gradually develops an outer cell mass of trophoblast cells, and an interior cell cluster with a fluid-filled cavity at the core called the blastocoel. As the blastocoel forms, the morula becomes a blastocyst.  

The cells making up the inner cell wall of the blastocyst are collectively called the embryoblast. The embryoblast cells cluster together at one end of the blastocyst in an area called the embryonic pole. The trophoblast cells flatten out into a barrier around the blastocyst. Fully formed, the blastocyst hatches from the zona pellucida around the end of day four and attaches itself to the uterus wall.  


Option Analysis

❌ On the day of fertilization  :
Incorrect: The zygote is formed on the day of fertilization.  
❌ Week 4 of fertilization  :
Incorrect: The neural tube is formed neuroectoderm and closes by week 4.  
❌ Day 3 of fertilization  :
Incorrect: The morula enters the uterus 3-4 days after fertilization and becomes a blastocyst on day 6 of fertilization.  
✅ Day 6 of fertilization  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Week 2 of fertilization  :
Incorrect: The Bilaminar disc (epiblast, hypoblast) forms in week 2 of fertilization.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man undergoes inferior parathyroid gland removal. This portion of the parathyroid gland is a component of the pharyngeal apparatus and is derived from which of the following germ layers?
questions.solution:
The inferior parathyroid gland is a derivative of a pharyngeal pouch, one of the components of the pharyngeal apparatus. The pharyngeal apparatus is the complex region in the developing embryo between the head and chest that develops in the fourth week and subsequently develops into numerous structures of the head, face, palate, and anterior neck. It consists of:  

  •  Pharyngeal clefts—derived from ectoderm. Also called pharyngeal grooves. It forms structures in the ear canals. 
  •  Pharyngeal arches—are derived from mesoderm (muscles, arteries) and neural crest (bones, cartilage). 
  •  Pharyngeal pouches—derived from endoderm. These form parts of the ears, the early tonsils, and many portions of the parathyroid glands and thyroid. 


Option Analysis

❌ Surface ectoderm:
Incorrect: The pharyngeal clefts are derived from the ectoderm. The inferior parathyroid gland is not its derivative.  
✅ Endoderm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mesoderm:
Incorrect: Pharyngeal arches are derived from mesoderm (muscles, arteries) and neural crest (bones, cartilage). The inferior parathyroid gland is not its derivative.  
❌ Neural tube  :
Incorrect: Neural tube derivatives include the brain (neurohypophysis, CNS neurons, oligodendrocytes,  astrocytes, ependymal cells, pineal gland), retina, and spinal cord.  
❌ Neural crest  :
Incorrect:  Pharyngeal arches are derived from mesoderm (muscles, arteries) and neural crest (bones, cartilage). The inferior parathyroid gland is not its derivative.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the process of human development. He discovers an embryological structure that induces the ectoderm to differentiate into the neuroectoderm and form the neural plate. The embryological structure described by the investigator forms one of the following in adults?
questions.solution:
Around day 17, a group of axial mesoderm cells forms a solid rod of cells called the notochord. Notochord becomes the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc in adults. The notochord induces overlying ectoderm to differentiate into neuroectoderm and create a neural plate. The neural plate gives rise to neural tube and neural crest cells.  

Option Analysis

❌ Rathke pouch  :
Incorrect: The anterior pituitary is derived from the Rathke pouch, an evagination of the surface ectoderm that lines the fetal oral cavity.  
✅ Nucleus pulposus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Parafollicular (C) cells  :
Incorrect: Parafollicular (C) cells are derived from the endoderm.  
❌ Schwann cells  :
Incorrect: Schwann cells are derived from neural crest cells.  
❌ Olfactory epithelium  :
Incorrect: Olfactory epithelium is a derivative of surface ectoderm.

questions.text: A 6- year-old girl presents to the office to evaluate dry skin, fatigue, sensitivity to cold, and constipation. The patient’s mother recalls that the patient had surgery to remove a “benign mass” at the base of her tongue three months ago because of trouble swallowing. Which of the following best describes the embryological origin of this mass?
questions.solution:
This child has symptoms of hypothyroidism with a history of surgical removal of a tongue mass. These findings suggest a lingual thyroid consisting of thyroid tissue that failed to migrate to its normal position at the base of the neck during embryologic development.

The thyroid gland develops from the endoderm at the base of the tongue, independent of the pharyngeal apparatus. As the embryo grows, the thyroid descends the neck and the parathyroid glands.  

Option Analysis

❌ Surface ectoderm:
Incorrect: Surface ectoderm derivatives include the epidermis, adenohypophysis, the lens of the eye, epithelial linings of the oral cavity, sensory organs of the ear, and olfactory epithelium; anal canal below the pectinate line, parotid, sweat, and mammary glands.  
✅ Endoderm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mesoderm:
Incorrect: Mesoderm derivatives include muscle, bone, connective tissue, serous linings of body cavities (e.g., peritoneum, pericardium, pleura), spleen (develops within foregut mesentery), cardiovascular structures, lymphatics, blood, wall of the gut tube, upper vagina, kidneys, adrenal cortex, dermis, testes, ovaries, microglia.  
❌ Neural tube:
Incorrect: Neural tube derivatives include the brain (neurohypophysis, CNS neurons, oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, ependymal cells, pineal gland), retina, and spinal cord.  
❌ Neural crest  :
Incorrect: Neural crest derivatives include melanocytes, odontoblasts, tracheal cartilage, enterochromaffin cells, leptomeninges (arachnoid, pia), PNS ganglia (cranial, dorsal root, autonomic), adrenal medulla, Schwann cells, spiral membrane (aorticopulmonary septum), endocardial cushions (also derived partially from mesoderm) and skull bones.

questions.text: The process of human development involves the development of a bilaminar disc which consists of two layers of cells. Which of the following structures is formed by the ventral hypoblast layer of the bilaminar disc?
questions.solution:
During the second week of fertilization, the embryoblast differentiates into two layers forming a flat structure called the bilaminar embryonic disc:  

Hypoblast (ventral side): small cuboidal cells adjacent to the blastocyst give rise to the yolk sac and extraembryonic mesoderm cells.  

Epiblast (dorsal side): columnar cells give rise to all three germ layers of the embryo (endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm).  

The amniotic cavity develops just above the bilaminar disc, and it gets lined with epiblast cells.  



Option Analysis

❌ Ectoderm:
Incorrect: The ectoderm is formed by the dorsal side epiblast layer of the bilaminar disc.  
❌ Endoderm:
Incorrect: The endoderm is formed by the dorsal side epiblast layer of the bilaminar disc.  
❌ Mesoderm:
Incorrect: The mesoderm is formed by the dorsal side epiblast layer of the bilaminar disc.  
❌ Amniotic cavity  :
Incorrect: The amniotic cavity is formed by the dorsal side epiblast layer of the bilaminar disc.  
✅ Yolk sac  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A primigravid 28-year-old woman delivers a male infant who is found to have underdeveloped hands, and a radiograph reveals missing thumb phalanges. The infant has difficulty feeding, which results in coughing and apnea. Examination of the buttocks reveals an absent anus. Further workup reveals flow between the two ventricles on echocardiography and a single kidney on preliminary abdominal ultrasound. Which of the following embryological tissues was most likely affected during embryologic development?
questions.solution:
This infant most likely has VACTERL syndrome resulting from mesodermal derivative defects.  VACTERL is a constellation of defects that result from the improper mesodermal formation. It includes vertebral defects (misshapen or fused vertebrae, missing vertebrae), anal atresia or improper anus formation, cardiac defects ranging from mild to severe, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal defects (missing kidneys, abnormally developed kidneys, misshapen kidneys), and limb defects (most commonly missing thumbs and poorly developed forearms and hands). A deficiency in the embryological mesoderm causes this syndrome during development.  

Option Analysis

❌ Surface ectoderm  :
Incorrect: Surface ectoderm defects can result in a craniopharyngioma but do not cause the set of defects seen in VACTERL syndrome.
❌ Endoderm:
 Incorrect: Endoderm is the innermost of the three primary germ layers in the very early embryo. Its embryological derivatives include gut tube epithelium (including anal canal above the pectinate line), most of the urethra and lower vagina (derived from urogenital sinus), and luminal epithelial derivatives (e.g., lungs, liver, gallbladder, pancreas, eustachian tube, thymus, parathyroid, thyroid follicular and parafollicular [C] cells).  
✅ Mesoderm:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Neural tube  :
Incorrect: Neural tube derivatives include the brain (neurohypophysis, CNS neurons, oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, ependymal cells, pineal gland), retina, and spinal cord. The clinical syndrome seen in this patient would not result from failure of neural tube differentiation.  
❌ Neural crest  :
 Incorrect: Neural crest derivatives include melanocytes, odontoblasts, tracheal cartilage, enterochromaffin cells, leptomeninges (arachnoid, pia), PNS ganglia (cranial, dorsal root, autonomic), adrenal medulla, Schwann cells, spiral membrane (aorticopulmonary septum), endocardial cushions (also derived partially from mesoderm) and skull bones.

questions.text:
An examiner presents a radiograph of a 5-month-old boy to a student and identifies a structure in the anterior superior mediastinum that involutes at the age of three years. This structure has which of the following embryological origins?
 

Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
The thymus is located in the anterior superior mediastinum. Its epithelium is derived from the third pharyngeal pouch (endoderm). The normal neonatal thymic is “sail-shaped” on the chest x-ray and involutes by age three. The thymic sail sign represents a triangular-shaped inferior margin of the normal thymus seen on a neonatal frontal chest radiograph. It is seen in 3-15% of all cases.  

Option Analysis

❌ First pharyngeal arch:
Incorrect: The first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the mandible, malleus, incus, muscles of mastication, mylohyoid, tensor tympani, tensor veli palatini, CN V2/V3, maxillary artery, and external carotid artery.  
❌ First pharyngeal cleft  :
Incorrect: The first pharyngeal cleft develops into the external auditory meatus.  
❌ Third pharyngeal arch:
Incorrect: The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to the greater horn of the hyoid, stylopharyngeus muscle, CN IX, common carotid artery, and internal carotid artery.  
✅ Third pharyngeal pouch  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fourth pharyngeal cleft  :
Incorrect: The fourth pharyngeal cleft and the second and third are typically obliterated later in development. Remnants of these clefts may present as cervical cysts in the lateral neck.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying fetal erythropoiesis at different stages of fetal development.  Which organ is expected to be the primary center for fetal erythropoiesis at 9 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Fetal erythropoiesis, or the development of fetal red blood cells, occurs in different organs at different stages of fetal development. At 9 weeks of gestation, the primary site of fetal erythropoiesis is the liver. Outlined below are the relative times and locations of erythropoiesis in the developing fetus.  

  • Yolk sac (3–8 weeks)  
  • Liver (6 weeks–birth)  
  • Spleen (10–28 weeks)  
  • Bone marrow (18 weeks to adult)  

Option Analysis

✅ Liver:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Yolk Sac  :
Incorrect: The yolk sac serves as the primary site of erythropoiesis until approximately 6-8 weeks gestation.
❌ Bone marrow  :
Incorrect: Bone marrow is the primary site of erythropoiesis following birth; it is a minor site of erythropoiesis in the developing fetus until the third trimester.  
❌ Skeletal muscle  :
Incorrect: Skeletal muscle is not a primary site of erythropoiesis in the developing fetus.  
❌ Kidneys:
Incorrect: Kidneys are not a primary site of erythropoiesis in the developing fetus.

questions.text: An experiment is performed to understand the steps of fertilization. In one study, a researcher removes cortical granules from the egg. Which of the following is expected to be observed during the fertilization process of this egg?

choices.text: Inability of sperm to enter the egg
Inability of sperm to fuse nuclear material

questions.solution:
Typically, fertilization occurs when one sperm enters the egg, and their nuclear material fuse to make a complete set of chromosomes and eventually forms the zygote and future embryo.  

Around 10,000 sperms reach the fallopian tube and can fertilize the egg. However, only one sperm may enter the egg to form a normal zygote. The entrance of more than one sperm into the egg is called polyspermy.  If more than one sperm enters the egg due to a failure in cortication, the developing embryo may acquire an abnormal set of chromosomes (triploid chromosomes).  

To prevent polyspermy, cortical granules found in the cytosol of the ovaries initiate the cortical reaction. Once a single sperm enters the egg, calcium levels rise, signaling cortical granules to fuse with the egg's plasma membrane. This forms a hyaline membrane layer that prevents additional sperm from entering the egg. If the cortical reaction fails, other sperm can enter the egg, resulting in polyspermy.  


Option Analysis

✅ Polyspermy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Monospermy:
Incorrect: Monospermy refers to the entrance of only one sperm into the egg. The cortical reaction prevents more than one sperm from entering the egg.  
❌ No significant abnormality  :
Incorrect: The cortical reaction prevents more than one sperm from entering the egg. Therefore, without it, polyspermy is expected to develop.  
❌ Inability of sperm to enter the egg  :
Incorrect: The cortical reaction prevents more than one sperm from entering the egg.  Therefore, without it, polyspermy is expected to develop.  
❌ Inability of sperm to fuse nuclear material  :
Incorrect: The cortical reaction prevents more than one sperm from entering the egg. The ability of sperm to fuse their nuclear material with the egg remains unaffected.

questions.text: A 1-hour-old boy is noted to have meconium discharge from the umbilicus. Which of the following embryological structures is associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
In early embryonic life, the omphalomesenteric (vitelline) duct connects the midgut lumen with the yolk sac cavity. The allantois, the vitelline duct, and the body stalk combine to form the umbilical cord.  

The vitelline duct obliterates typically during the 7th week of embryonic development—a complete failure of the vitelline duct to close results in a persistent vitelline duct. A small connection between the intestinal lumen and the outside of the body exists at the umbilicus.   

Option Analysis

✅ Omphalomesenteric duct  :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Umbilical vein  :
Incorrect: The umbilical vein transports oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetal circulation. It obliterates soon after birth and is replaced by the round ligament of the liver.  
❌ Paramesonephric duct  :
Incorrect: The paramesonephric duct (Mullerian duct) develops into the female internal reproductive organs (uterus, fallopian tubes, and inner vagina).  
❌ Urachus:
Incorrect: The urachus is a channel between the fetal bladder and umbilicus that allows urine to drain during the first trimester of pregnancy. If the urachus fails to obliterate, a patent urachus will lead to urine drainage from the umbilicus at birth.  
❌ Ductus venosus  :
Incorrect: The ductus venosus is a fetal structure that joins the left portal vein to the left hepatic vein. The ligamentum venosum is the fibrous remnant of the ductus venosus. It courses along the posterior aspect of the liver.

questions.text: Scientists are studying human lung development. Which of the following best describes the gestation age at which the surfactant achieves mature levels?
questions.solution:
A surfactant is a fluid in the alveoli that decreases surface tension at the blood-air barrier by lowering the attractive forces between water molecules. This allows the lungs to fill with air more easily, and prevents the collapse of alveoli during expiration. Synthesis of surfactant begins at ~20 weeks’ gestation and achieves mature levels at ~35 weeks of gestation.  

Option Analysis

❌ 4 weeks  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. At 4 weeks gestation, the lung bud sprouts from the foregut portion of the digestive tract.  
❌ 17 weeks:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Between weeks 5-17, the endodermal tubules form terminal bronchioles. Respiration is impossible at this stage.  
❌ 20 weeks:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. The surfactant starts to be produced at 20 weeks gestation.  
❌ 25 weeks:
Incorrect:  This answer choice is incorrect. By 25 weeks gestation, the terminal bronchioles have differentiated into respiratory bronchioles and eventually alveolar ducts. Although the fetus is capable of respiration, the surfactant has not reached its mature levels.  
✅ 35 weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A patient with suspected appendicitis demonstrates maximal tenderness over the right lower abdomen, two-thirds of the distance from the umbilicus to the anterior superior iliac spine. This inflamed gastrointestinal lining originates from which of the following embryological layers?
questions.solution:
Inflammation of the appendix irritates the parietal peritoneum, causing severe somatic pain at McBurney’s point. The parietal peritoneum is derived from mesoderm.  

The mesoderm is one of three germinal layers that appear in the third week of embryonic development and is found between the ectoderm and endoderm. Mesoderm derivatives include muscle, bone, connective tissue, serous linings of body cavities (e.g., peritoneum, pericardium, pleura), spleen (develops within foregut mesentery), cardiovascular structures, lymphatics, blood, wall of the gut tube, upper vagina, kidneys, adrenal cortex, dermis, testes, ovaries, and microglia.

Option Analysis

❌ Surface ectoderm  :
Incorrect: Surface ectoderm derivatives include the epidermis, adenohypophysis, the lens of the eye, epithelial linings of the oral cavity, sensory organs of the ear, and olfactory epithelium; anal canal below the pectinate line, parotid, sweat, and mammary glands.  
❌ Endoderm:
Incorrect: Endoderm is the innermost of the three primary germ layers in the very early embryo. Its embryological derivatives include gut tube epithelium (including the anal canal above the pectinate line), most of the urethra and lower vagina (derived from urogenital sinus), and luminal epithelial derivatives (e.g., lungs, liver, gallbladder, pancreas, eustachian tube, thymus, parathyroid, thyroid follicular and parafollicular [C] cells).  
✅ Mesoderm:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Neural tube  :
Incorrect: Neural tube derivatives include the brain (neurohypophysis, CNS neurons, oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, ependymal cells, pineal gland), retina, and spinal cord.  
❌ Neural crest  :
Incorrect: Neural crest derivatives include melanocytes, odontoblasts, tracheal cartilage, enterochromaffin cells, leptomeninges (arachnoid, pia), PNS ganglia (cranial, dorsal root, autonomic), adrenal medulla, Schwann cells, spiral membrane (aorticopulmonary septum), endocardial cushions (also derived partially from mesoderm) and skull bones.

questions.text: A 2-week-old boy is noted to have a clear to straw-colored discharge from the umbilicus when pressure is applied to the child’s lower abdomen. No bilious or feculent drainage is indicated. Which of the following embryological structures is associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Around three weeks gestation, the yolk sac forms a protrusion called the allantois that extends into the urogenital sinus. The upper part of the urogenital sinus gives rise to the bladder. The allantois, which initially connected the urogenital sinus with the yolk sac, becomes the urachus, a duct between the bladder and the yolk sac. The urachus obliterates typically during the 12th week of gestation and becomes the median umbilical ligament. A complete failure of the urachus to obliterate before birth results in patent urachus. Patients present with straw-colored urine discharge from the umbilicus.  

Option Analysis

❌ Omphalomesenteric duct  :
Incorrect: The omphalomesenteric duct (vitelline duct) is a fetal structure that connects the midgut lumen to the yolk sac in the developing embryo. A Meckel's diverticulum or persistent vitelline duct may develop if the omphalomesenteric duct fails to obliterate during the seventh week of embryological development.  
❌ Umbilical vein  :
Incorrect: The umbilical vein transports oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetal circulation. It obliterates soon after birth and is replaced by the round ligament of the liver.  
❌ Paramesonephric duct  :
Incorrect: The paramesonephric duct (Mullerian duct) develops into the female internal reproductive organs (uterus, fallopian tubes, and inner vagina).
✅ Urachus:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Ductus venosus  :
Incorrect: The ductus venosus is a fetal structure that joins the left portal vein to the left hepatic vein. The ligamentum venosum is the fibrous remnant of the ductus venosus. It courses along the posterior aspect of the liver.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, with an uncomplicated prenatal course delivers a 3.9-kg (8.6-lb) newborn at 38 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Further evaluation in the newborn nursery shows ambiguous genitalia. Karyotype analysis shows a 46, XY genotype. The uterus is absent on pelvic ultrasound. The absence of a uterus is due to the effects of which of the following substances during embryologic development?
questions.solution:
The human embryo initially forms undifferentiated gonads, genital ducts and primitive external genitalia (genital tubercle, folds and swellings). Their sequential differentiation gives rise to the male reproductive system.

1. Gonadal stage: The primordial germ cells originate near the yolk sac and migrate towards the genital ridge, forming primitive gonads. Under the influence of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome, male gonads begin to secrete testosterone from Leydig cells and mullerian-inhibiting factor (MIF) from Sertoli cells.

2. Ductal stage: In the male embryo, MIF causes the paramesonephric (mullerian) ducts to regress, while the mesonephric ducts develop into the epididymis, ductus deferens and seminal vesicles. In females, mullerian ducts develop into the uterus, cervix and upper part of vagina.

3. Genital stage: The genital tubercle gives rise to glans penis in males. The urogenital folds transform into the ventral aspect of the penis. The genital swellings become the scrotum. The urogenital sinus gives rise to the bladder, urethra, prostate, and bulbourethral glands.  

Option Analysis

❌ Testosterone:
Incorrect: Testosterone is produced by Leydig cells of the testes. During embryogenesis, it is responsible for development of the internal male genitalia. It is not involved in regression of the mullerian duct.  
❌ Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)  :
Incorrect: Dihydrotestosterone is an active metabolite of testosterone. During embryonic life, it mediates formation of the male external genitalia, while in the adult, it is responsible for development of male secondary sex characteristics.  
❌ Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA)  :
Incorrect: Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) is a sex hormone precursor produced by the adrenal gland. It is not known to play a role in sexual differentiation.  
❌ Luteinizing hormone (LH)  :
Incorrect: Luteinizing hormone (LH) is produced by the anterior pituitary gland. In the males, it is tropic to Leydig cells and stimulates testosterone production. In females, it is responsible for maturation of the ovarian follicles, ovulation, and formation of the corpus luteum.  
✅ Mullerian inhibitory factor (MIF)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A tiny space called the amniotic cavity forms in the blastocyst during day eight of fetal development. This cavity is surrounded by cells called the amnion. The amnion is derived from which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
During day 8 of fetal development, a tiny space called the amniotic cavity forms between the epiblast and cytotrophoblast. The epiblast cells migrate to form a thin membrane called the amnion that surrounds the amniotic cavity, separating it from the cytotrophoblast.  

During day 9, hypoblast cells begin to migrate to form a thin membrane lining the rest of the blastocoel, forming the walls of the yolk sac.  

Option Analysis

✅ Epiblast:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Hypoblast:
Incorrect: During day 9, hypoblast cells begin to migrate and form a thin membrane lining the rest of the blastocoel, forming the walls of the yolk sac.  
❌ Cytotrophoblast:
Incorrect: The cytotrophoblast forms the inner layer of the trophoblast. It is interior to the syncytiotrophoblast and external to the blastocyst wall in a developing embryo. It does not form the amnion.  
❌ Syncytiotrophoblast:
Incorrect: The syncytiotrophoblast forms the epithelial covering the highly vascular embryonic (not maternal) placental villi, which invade the uterus wall to establish circulation between the embryo and mother.  
❌ Extraembryonic mesoderm  :
Incorrect: By day 10 of fetal development, some epiblast cells differentiate into extraembryonic mesoderm and settle between the amniotic cavity and the cytotrophoblast, creating a thick layer of extraembryonic mesoderm tissue between the two. Over time, a space forms within this thick layer of extraembryonic mesoderm.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying fetal circulation and fetal-postnatal derivatives. They identify a blood vessel that immediately drains from the placenta bringing highly oxygenated blood to the fetus. This structure becomes which of the following fetal-postnatal derivatives?
questions.solution:
The structure described in the question stem is the umbilical vein, which becomes the round ligament of the liver in the postnatal period. Multiple fetal circulatory structures and their derivatives are outlined in the diagram below.  

After birth, Wharton's Jelly (which surrounds the umbilical cord) shrinks upon exposure to cold air, resulting in vasoconstriction of the umbilical arteries and veins housed within the cord. Over time, these vessels further shrink and flatten, resulting in their postnatal derivatives. Additional changes that occur include a decrease in pulmonary circulatory pressure and a rise in systemic pressure due to the neonates’ lungs being filled with air instead of fluid. This results in decreased right-sided heart pressures, with subsequent closure of the ductus arteriosus, and closing of the foramen ovale.  


Option Analysis

✅ Round ligament of the liver  :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Superior vesical arteries  :
Incorrect: The superior vesical arteries are remnants of the umbilical arteries, not umbilical veins.  
❌ Ligamentum venosum  :
Incorrect: The ligamentum venosum is a remnant of the ductus venosus.
❌ Foramen ovalis  :
Incorrect: The Fossa ovalis is a remnant of the foramen ovale.  
❌ Ligamentum arteriosum  :
Incorrect: The ligamentum arteriosum is a remnant of the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: The respiratory system develops during week 4 of intrauterine life and begins when a lung bud sprouts from the primitive digestive tract. Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding the development of the respiratory system?

choices.text: The respiratory diverticulum appears as an outgrowth from the ventral wall of the foregut at 12 weeks gestation.
The epithelium of the internal lining of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi is of mesodermal origin.
There is no direct communication between the lung bud and foregut during the development.
The tracheoesophageal septum divides the foregut into a dorsal portion, the esophagus and a ventral portion, the trachea.
Isolated esophageal atresia comprises 90% of the developmental abnormalities of the trachea and esophagus.

questions.solution:
The respiratory system starts developing during week 4 of intrauterine life, and it begins when a lung bud sprouts out of the primitive digestive tract. Initially, the lung bud is in open communication with the foregut. During week 4, two tracheoesophageal ridges form and grow towards one another, ultimately fusing into a septum that divides the foregut into two regions: a dorsal esophagus and a ventral lung bud.

The lung bud contains an endoderm core, which develops into the epithelial and glandular structures of the trachea and lungs, surrounded by visceral mesoderm. Now, the lung bud basically just hangs off the foregut, and at its loose end it bifurcates into two bronchial buds. These bronchial buds give rise to the lungs, which grow and develop inside the pleural cavities.

Abnormalities in partitioning of the esophagus and trachea by the tracheoesophageal  septum results in esophageal atresia with or without tracheoesophageal fistulas (TEFs). The most frequent abnormality (90% of cases) occurs with the upper esophagus ending in a blind pouch and the lower segment forming a fistula with the trachea.


Option Analysis

❌ The respiratory diverticulum appears as an outgrowth from the ventral wall of the foregut at 12 weeks gestation.  :
Incorrect: The respiratory diverticulum appears as an outgrowth from the ventral wall of the foregut at 4 weeks gestation.  
❌ The epithelium of the internal lining of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi is of mesodermal origin.:
Incorrect: The epithelium of the internal lining of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi as well as that of the lung bud is of endodermal origin.  
❌ There is no direct communication between the lung bud and foregut during the development.:
Incorrect: Initially, the lung bud is in open communication with the foregut before the formation of the tracheoesophageal septum.  
✅ The tracheoesophageal septum divides the foregut into a dorsal portion, the esophagus and a ventral portion, the trachea.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Isolated esophageal atresia comprises 90% of the developmental abnormalities of the trachea and esophagus.:
Incorrect: The most frequent developmental abnormality of the trachea and esophagus  (90% of cases) occurs with the upper esophagus ending in a blind pouch and the lower segment forming a fistula with the trachea.

questions.text: Genetic testing confirms a gene mutation that results in abnormal development of the first and second pharyngeal arches. A full-term neonate with respiratory depression is examined in the intensive care unit and shows an underdeveloped jaw with a backward displacement of the tongue, an underdeveloped mandible, and hypoplastic zygomatic bones. Which of the following additional structures is likely abnormal in this patient?
questions.solution:
This neonate's presentation is consistent with the Pierre Robin sequence, a genetic disorder resulting in the abnormal development of the first and second pharyngeal arches.  This disorder is characterized by an underdeveloped jaw, backward tongue displacement, and upper airway obstruction. Cleft palate is often present as well.

The first pharyngeal arch is associated with the trigeminal nerve (CN V). Its bony derivatives include the maxilla, zygoma, mandible, incus, and malleus; its muscular derivatives include muscles of mastication (e.g., masseter, temporalis). The second pharyngeal arch is associated with the facial nerve (CN VII) and gives rise to the styloid process of the temporal bone, the lesser horn of the hyoid, and stapes. Muscular derivatives of the second arch include the muscles of mastication.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cricoid cartilage  :
Incorrect: The fourth and sixth arches comprise the cartilaginous structures of the larynx, including the cricoid and thyroid cartilage.  
❌ Glossopharyngeal nerve:
Incorrect: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) is derived from the third pharyngeal arch. Dysfunction may lead to poor taste perception and an absent gag reflex.  
✅ Maxilla:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thyroid cartilage  :
Incorrect: The fourth and sixth arches comprise the cartilaginous structures of the larynx, including the cricoid and thyroid cartilage.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve (CN X) is derived from the fourth and sixth arches. Dysfunction results in laryngeal and pharyngeal paralysis and autonomic dysfunction (e.g., esophageal motility, gastric acid secretion, and heart variability).

questions.text: An investigator is studying the development of the female reproductive system in a human embryo. Which of the following structures is the embryological origin of the adult human cervix?
questions.solution:
The human embryo initially forms undifferentiated gonads, genital ducts, and primitive external genitalia (genital tubercle, folds, and swellings). Their sequential differentiation gives rise to the female reproductive system.
  1.  Gonadal stage: The primordial germ cells originate near the yolk sac and migrate towards the genital ridge, forming primitive gonads. In the absence of testis-determining factor by the SRY gene on the Y chromosome, the gonads differentiate into ovaries.
  2. Ductal stage: In the female embryo, sertoli cells are not formed, thus mullerian-inhibiting factor (MIF) is not secreted. In this instance, the mullerian (paramesonephric) ducts give rise to the uterine tubes (later forms uterus), cervix, and upper vagina under the influence of maternal estrogen. The mesonephric ducts regress.
  3. Genital stage: The genital tubercle gives rise to glans clitoris in females. The genital folds transform into the labia minora in females. The genital swellings become the labia majora. The urogenital sinus develops into the bladder, urethra, lower vagina, and Bartholin glands. 

Option Analysis

❌ Wolffian duct (mesonephric duct)  :
Incorrect: The mesonephric ducts regress in females. In the males, they develop into the epididymis, ductus deferens, and seminal vesicles.  
❌ Genital tubercle  :
Incorrect: The genital tubercle gives rise to glans clitoris in females. It is not involved in the development of internal genitalia.  
✅ Mullerian duct (paramesonephric duct)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rathke pouch:
Incorrect: The anterior pituitary is derived from Rathke pouch, an evagination of the surface ectoderm that lines the fetal oral cavity. The anterior pituitary gland has gonadotropes that secrete luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH). However, they are not involved in the formation of internal genitalia.  
❌ Urogenital sinus:
Incorrect: In females, the urogenital sinus develops into the bladder, urethra, lower vagina, and Bartholin glands. It is not involved in the formation of the uterus, cervix, and upper vagina.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl complains of severe ear pain and yellow discharge from her left ear for two days. The pain started during her last day of summer camp, where she spent a lot of time outdoors. Examination demonstrates tragal tenderness and a red and edematous external auditory canal. The component of the ear associated with this patient's condition arises from which embryological structures?
questions.solution:
The first pharyngeal cleft develops into the external auditory meatus. The second to fourth pharyngeal clefts form temporary cervical sinuses obliterated in utero by the rapid growth of the second pharyngeal arch, and they do not differentiate into any of the head and neck structures.  

Option Analysis

❌ First pharyngeal arch:
Incorrect: The first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the mandible, malleus, incus, muscles of mastication, mylohyoid, tensor tympani, tensor veli palatini, CN V2/V3, maxillary artery, and external carotid artery.  
✅ First pharyngeal cleft  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Third pharyngeal arch:
Incorrect: The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to the greater horn of the hyoid, stylopharyngeus muscle, CN IX, common carotid artery, and internal carotid artery.  
❌ Third pharyngeal pouch:
Incorrect: The third pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the thymus and the inferior parathyroids.  
❌ Fourth pharyngeal cleft  :
Incorrect: The fourth pharyngeal cleft and the second and third are typically obliterated later in development. Remnants of these clefts may present as cervical cysts in the lateral neck.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office for evaluation of amenorrhea. She has never menstruated, has no chronic medical conditions and takes no medications. Physical examination shows fully developed secondary sexual characteristics. Pelvic ultrasound shows a shortened vaginal canal with a rudimentary uterus. Lack of development of which of the following embryological structures is the most likely cause of the abnormal findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
The human embryo initially forms undifferentiated gonads, genital ducts and primitive external genitalia (genital tubercle, folds and swellings). Their sequential differentiation gives rise to the female reproductive system.

  1. Gonadal stage: In the absence of testis-determining factor by the SRY gene on the Y chromosome, the gonads differentiate into ovaries. 
  2. Ductal stage: In the female embryo, since sertoli cells are not formed, mullerian-inhibiting factor (MIF) is not secreted. In this instance, the mullerian (paramesonephric) ducts give rise to the uterine tubes (later forms uterus), cervix, and upper vagina under the influence of maternal estrogen. The mesonephric ducts regress.
  3. Genital stage: The genital tubercle gives rise to glans clitoris in females. The genital folds transform into the labia minora. The genital swellings become the labia majora. The urogenital sinus forms the lower vagina.
Failure of the mullerian duct development leads to Müllerian agenesis (also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) which may present as primary amenorrhea (due to a lack of uterine development) with fully developed secondary sexual characteristics (functional ovaries).  

Option Analysis

❌ Wolffian duct (mesonephric duct)  :
Incorrect: The mesonephric ducts regress in females. In the males, they develop into the epididymis, ductus deferens and seminal vesicles.  
❌ Genital tubercle  :
Incorrect: The genital tubercle gives rise to glans clitoris in females. It is not involved in the development of internal genitalia.  
✅ Mullerian duct (paramesonephric duct)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Rathke pouch:
Incorrect: The anterior pituitary is derived from Rathke pouch, an evagination of the surface ectoderm that lines the fetal oral cavity. The anterior pituitary gland houses gonadotropes that secrete luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH). However, they are not involved in the pathogenesis of mullerian agenesis.  
❌ Urogenital sinus  :
Incorrect: In females, the urogenital sinus develops into the bladder, urethra, lower vagina and Bartholin glands. It is not involved in the formation of the uterus, cervix and upper vagina.

questions.text: An error occurs during the embryologic development of a fetus’ kidney. It is found that the fetus lacks proper ureters, collecting ducts, major and minor calyces, and renal pelvises. The organs absent in this fetus typically originate from which of the following embryological layers?
questions.solution:
The mesoderm is one of three germinal layers that appear in the third week of embryonic development. It is found between the ectoderm and endoderm. Its derivatives include muscle, bone, connective tissue, serous linings of body cavities (e.g., peritoneum, pericardium, pleura), spleen (develops within foregut mesentery), cardiovascular structures, lymphatics, blood, wall of the gut tube, upper vagina, kidneys, adrenal cortex, dermis, testes, ovaries, and microglia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Surface ectoderm  :
Incorrect: Surface ectoderm derivatives include the epidermis, adenohypophysis, eye lens, epithelial linings of the oral cavity, sensory organs of the ear, and olfactory epithelium; anal canal below the pectinate line, parotid, sweat, and mammary glands.  
❌ Endoderm:
Incorrect: Endoderm is the innermost of the three primary germ layers in the very early embryo. Its embryological derivatives include gut tube epithelium (including anal canal above the pectinate line), most of the urethra and lower vagina (derived from urogenital sinus), and luminal epithelial derivatives (e.g., lungs, liver, gallbladder, pancreas, eustachian tube, thymus, parathyroid, thyroid follicular and parafollicular [C] cells).  
✅ Mesoderm:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Neural tube  :
Incorrect: Neural tube derivatives include the brain (neurohypophysis, CNS neurons, oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, ependymal cells, pineal gland), retina, and spinal cord.  
❌ Neural crest  :
Incorrect: Neural crest derivatives include melanocytes, odontoblasts, tracheal cartilage, enterochromaffin cells, leptomeninges (arachnoid, pia), PNS ganglia (cranial, dorsal root, autonomic), adrenal medulla, Schwann cells, spiral membrane (aorticopulmonary septum), endocardial cushions (also derived partially from mesoderm) and skull bones.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for an elective cholecystectomy secondary to symptomatic cholethiasis. The diseased organ/structure in this patient originated from which of the following embryological layers?
questions.solution:
Endoderm is the innermost of the three primary germ layers during early embryological development. Its embryological derivatives include gut tube epithelium (including anal canal above the pectinate line), most of the urethra and lower vagina (derived from urogenital sinus), and luminal epithelial derivatives (e.g., lungs, liver, gallbladder, pancreas, eustachian tube, thymus, parathyroid, thyroid follicular and parafollicular [C] cells).  

Option Analysis

❌ Surface ectoderm  :
Incorrect: Surface ectoderm derivatives include the epidermis, adenohypophysis, eye lens, epithelial linings of the oral cavity, sensory organs of the ear, and olfactory epithelium; anal canal below the pectinate line, parotid, sweat, and mammary glands.  
✅ Endoderm:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Mesoderm:
Incorrect: Mesoderm derivatives include muscle, bone, connective tissue, serous linings of body cavities (e.g., peritoneum, pericardium, pleura), spleen (develops within foregut mesentery), cardiovascular structures, lymphatics, blood, wall of the gut tube, upper vagina, kidneys, adrenal cortex, dermis, testes, ovaries, microglia.  
❌ Neural tube  :
Incorrect: Neural tube derivatives include the brain (neurohypophysis, CNS neurons, oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, ependymal cells, pineal gland), retina, and spinal cord.  
❌ Neural crest  :
Incorrect: Neural crest derivatives include melanocytes, odontoblasts, tracheal cartilage, enterochromaffin cells, leptomeninges (arachnoid, pia), PNS ganglia (cranial, dorsal root, autonomic), adrenal medulla, schwann cells, spiral membrane (aorticopulmonary septum), endocardial cushions (also derived partially from mesoderm) and skull bones.

questions.text: A group of investigators discovers that the umbilical cord structure consists of a body stalk, vitelline duct, and allantois. These components regress during fetal life or following the birth of the fetus. Which of the following pairs best represents the umbilical cord component and its adult remnant?

choices.text: Umbilical vein - round ligament of liver

questions.solution:
During development, the fetus is connected to the placenta via the umbilical cord, a long, flexible stalk that contains two small arteries and a large vein. Deoxygenated fetal blood flows through the umbilical arteries to the placenta, picking up oxygen and glucose while removing carbon dioxide. Oxygenated blood flow toward the fetus’s heart through the umbilical vein.  

-The body stalk: a short band of extraembryonic mesoderm that connects the embryo to chorion at week 2  
-Vitelline duct: an open connection between yolk sac and midgut at week 3  
-The allantois: small hindgut out pocketing that grows into umbilical cord at week 3  

After umbilical cord formation, the vitelline duct and yolk sac shrink and eventually disappears. A Meckel's diverticulum may develop if the vitelline duct does not regress completely. The Allantois continues growing into the bladder, while Its remnant becomes the urachus (which ultimately reverts into the median umbilical ligament). The final umbilical cord contains two umbilical arteries, one umbilical vein, and a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly, protecting the umbilical vessels. Following birth, the umbilical vein becomes the round ligament of the liver, while the two umbilical arteries become the medial ligaments.  

Option Analysis

❌ Body stalk - medial ligaments  :
 Incorrect: The body stalk contains the umbilical vessels and is the first of three structures that make up the umbilical cord. As the amnion expands, it folds and covers the body stalk and vitelline duct, forming an outer membrane for the umbilical cord.
❌ Allantois - Meckel’s diverticulum  :
Incorrect: The allantois becomes the urachus, which ultimately regresses into the median umbilical ligament.  
✅ Umbilical vein - round ligament of liver  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Umbilical arteries - urachus  :
Incorrect: The umbilical arteries remnant in adults are medial ligaments.  
❌ Vitelline duct - median umbilical ligament  :
Incorrect: The vitelline duct regresses entirely but, in some cases, will leave behind a Meckel’s diverticulum.

questions.text: A newborn child is found to have a cleft palate defect involving the secondary palate. Abnormal development of which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The palate refers to the roof of the mouth. It is divided into two parts, the primary palate and secondary palate.  

The primary palate is a triangular piece of tissue located anteriorly. It is formed by fusion of the medial nasal processes, which develops into the intermaxillary segment and, eventually, the primary palate. Defects involving the primary palate can lead to cleft lip.  

The secondary palate is derived from the maxillary processes, which give rise to the lateral palatine shelves. The lateral palatine shelves then fuse with each other and the primary palate in front. Defects with lateral palatine shelf fusion can give rise to cleft palate. 

  

Option Analysis

❌ Second pharyngeal arch  :
Incorrect: This patient has been diagnosed with a cleft defect. The palate is derived from the first pharyngeal arch.  
❌ Mandibular process  :
Incorrect: The mandibular processes give rise to the lower lip and mandible but not the secondary palate.  
❌ Lateral nasal process  :
Incorrect: The lateral nasal process is involved in forming the alae of the nose. It does not contribute to formation of the secondary palate.  
❌ Medial nasal process  :
Incorrect: The medial nasal process gives rise to the primary palate. The medial nasal process is not involved in the formation of the secondary palate.  
✅ Lateral palatine shelf  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant is brought to the urology clinic for follow-up regarding abnormal scrotal swelling. Physical examination demonstrates transillumination of a fluid-filled sac within the left scrotum. The right scrotum appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this condition?

choices.text: Incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis
Faulty positioning of the genital tubercle
Failure of fusion of urethral folds
Abnormal dilatation of the pampiniform plexus of spermatic veins

questions.solution:
The processus vaginalis is an evagination of the peritoneal cavity that accompanies the descending testis into the scrotum. This narrow canal connecting the lumen of the vaginal process with the peritoneal cavity is obliterated at birth or shortly thereafter. The lower portion remains as a shut sac, which invests the surface of each testis, and is reflected on to the internal surface of the scrotum as tunica vaginalis. Hydrocele of the testis refers to the development of a fluid-filled peritoneal sac within the scrotum that results in incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Faulty positioning of the genital tubercle:
Incorrect: Faulty positioning of the genital tubercle in a male embryo leads to the development of abnormal opening of the penile urethra on its dorsal (top) surface, called epispadias.  
❌ Malunion of the labioscrotal swellings:
Incorrect: A bifid scrotum results from malunion of the labioscrotal (genital) swellings. In females, these swellings form the labia majora.  
❌ Failure of fusion of urethral folds  :
Incorrect: Hypospadias refers to the abnormal opening of the penile urethra on its ventral (under) surface due to failure of fusion of urethral folds.  
❌ Abnormal dilatation of the pampiniform plexus of spermatic veins  :
Incorrect: Abnormal dilatation of the pampiniform plexus of spermatic veins leads to the formation of varicocele. It is usually seen in post-pubertal males and does not transilluminate.

questions.text: Achondroplasia results from an activating mutation in fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3), leading to the inhibition of chondrocyte proliferation and disruption of endochondral ossification. Which of the following bones normally form via endochondral ossification?
questions.solution:
Achondroplasia affects endochondral ossification, the process that mediates development of the bones of the axial skeleton (vertebrae and ribs), appendicular skeleton (e.g. pelvic, shoulder girdles, bones in limbs) and base of skull. In endochondral bone formation,  mesenchymal cells differentiate into chondrocytes that create the cartilage matrix. Chondrocytes proliferate throughout childhood, forming an elongating cartilage template that progressively calcifies due to the coordinated effects of osteoblasts, osteoclasts, and blood vessels in the periosteum. Deposition of osteoid matrix over the septa of calcified cartilage matrix forms woven bone, which then undergoes remodeling.

On the contrary, the intramembranous ossification forms the bones of the calvarium, facial bones, and the clavicle. In intramembranous ossification, mesenchymal cells differentiate directly into osteoblasts and begin osteoid matrix secretion without the formation of cartilaginous bones.

Option Analysis

✅ Base of skull  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clavicles:
Incorrect: The clavicles develop via intramembranous ossification.  
❌ Parts of temporal bone  :
Incorrect: The parts of temporal bone develop via intramembranous ossification.  
❌ Mandible:
Incorrect: The mandible develops via intramembranous ossification.  
❌ Nasal bone:
Incorrect: The nasal bone develops by intramembranous ossification.
